This is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. The goal is to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy, which govern the global economic environment of business. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad. Prerequisites: ECON 001, ECON 002 (ECON 010 ongoing from Class of 2010), and MATH 104. Students cannot receive credit for both FNCE 101 and ECON 102. Wharton students are required to take FNCE 101.
This class is a “great opportunity to learn” macroeconomic analysis. Students found the material interesting but not very practical or relevant.
Professor Grochulski “was very methodical and thorough in his explanation of the material, yet he did not engage the class enough to keep people interested.” He “spoke in a monotone voice,” lacked “experience in teaching,” and would “read off of the PowerPoint, drawing very little interest from students.” However, he was “accessible to his students via email.”
Finance 101 is a requirement of the Wharton core and required of all Wharton undergraduates.

Finance 101 is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. The goal is to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy, which govern the global economic environment of business. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.

Overall, this course was described as “helpful” and intellectually stimulating. This course was heavily based on economics and discussed some concepts in BPUB 250 and ECON 10. Students said that the lectures, readings, and slides were organized and helpful. However, many students hoped the course could discuss “more applicable examples” instead of theories. Some students felt the homework seemed unrelated to the exams and hoped there were practice exams available.

Students described Professor Landry as “intelligent,” “funny,” and “engaging.” As an economist at the Federal Reserve, Professor Landry was very “informed” and was “extremely passionate about the course material.” Many praised Professor Landry for being “very accessible,” and students felt that he greatly “enjoy[ed] communicating with students.” Students also said Professor Landry taught at an acceptable pace. However, many students complained that Professor Landry was unable to convey information well due to his language barrier. Specifically, he was unable to answer students’ questions from time to time, and sometimes his lectures were confusing and hard to understand.

All Wharton students are required to take this course. Students cannot receive credit for both FNCE 101 and ECON 102 (ECON 4). The prerequisites of this course are ECON 10 (or ECON 1 and ECON 2) and MATH 104.

Monetary Economics and the Global Economy is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. The goal is to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy, which govern the global economic environment of business. FNCE 101 analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad. 

	Students described FNCE 101 as a “fantastic market analysis” that was a “good introduction to macroeconomics,” and focused on current “global financial developments.” They enjoyed the course, and found it “interesting” and “relevant to world events.” Many students reported that they “learned a lot” and came away with a strong “understanding of the material.” Furthermore, students described the assigned readings as “interesting” and “valuable.”

	Overall, students had nothing but high regards for Professor Siegel. Multiple students said that he was the “best professor” they ever had. This was due to his “engaging” lectures and ability to “convey the core macroeconomic material,” while also “relating course concepts to the world.” Students appreciated his “enthusiasm,” “approachability,” and “knowledge of markets and economics.” 

	FNCE 101 comes highly recommended to majors and non-majors alike, and was described by many students as “the best course at Wharton.” The workload was described as light with “minimal problem sets and readings.” However, a few students commented that it was “difficult to prepare for the midterm” because there was “so much information.” Prerequisites include: ECON 010 [or ECON 001, ECON 002] and MATH 104. Students cannot receive credit for both FNCE 101 and ECON 102 [ECON 4]. Wharton students are required to take FNCE 101.
